awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: "Double-Double Dating" of Detrital Monazite and Detrital Zircon: Quantifying Sediment Recycling in Tectonic Studies
awd_abstract_narration:
Many geoscientists have suggested that it is likely that sedimentary rocks are "recycled", i.e. sediment is first eroded from pre-existing sedimentary rocks, gets placed back into the hydrologic cycle, and then is once again deposited into a basin to become a new sedimentary rock. Although this is an important suggestion, there are limited data that quantify to what degree this process occurs. This research will test a new approach, using a novel and relatively inexpensive method utilizing chemical analysis and dating of uranium and thorium isotopes in order to provide this needed quantitative data. If these new methods are successful, they can be used by a wide variety of scientists to develop a much better understanding of the history of a sedimentary basin - information critical not only to academic scientists but to those in both the petroleum and economic minerals industry as well. In addition to the scientific goals of the research, the project train undergraduate and graduate students in an important STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) discipline, thus contributing to the education of the next generation of scientists. In addition, it will provide outreach to high schools for pathways for high school students to go into the earth sciences in both central New York and Kentucky, and will also facilitate the development of teaching modules for teachers and students based on the results of the research. Results of the research will be disseminated as peer-reviewed publications and as presentations at professional society meetings. Analytical data will be made available through publicly accessible online databases.

Consideration of sediment recycling in tectonic studies is critical for accurate assessment of tectonic reconstructions such as terrane movement and collisional histories.  Preliminary research indicates that some detrital monazite grains exhibit textural evidence of having formed diagenetically in an older clastic sequence (i.e. detrital diagenetic monazite) and therefore must be recycled. The principal investigators suggest that the detrital diagenetic grains are readily distinguishable, based on textures and ages, from detrital monazite derived from crystalline rocks in the source terranes. This project will test the effectiveness of this rapid approach for detecting recycling compared to the much more expensive and labor intensive method of "double dating" detrital zircon (i.e. Uranium-Lead geochronology combined with (Uranium-Thorium)/Helium thermochronology of the same crystal).  The principal investigators will perform textural analysis, using backscatter electron imaging of monazite crystals, to characterize grains identified as diagenetic detrital monazite versus detrital metamorphic/igneous monazite. These grains will then be dated using Thorium-Lead geochronologic techniques followed by (Uranium-Thorium-Samarium)/Helium dating to quantitatively establish if our rapid, qualitative approach is valid.  The researchers will also determine the Neodymium isotopic composition of the dated single monazite grains to determine if this is a new and useful approach to expand sedimentary provenance information. The isotopic methods will be applied to Neoproterozoic and Paleozoic sedimentary strata from the eastern United States.

por.por_cntn:
This research project was intended to evaluate tools for defining processes associated with the generation and transport of sediment (mainly sand) that results from erosion of mountain belts over time scales of hundreds of millions of years. The most widely used tool for determining sediment pathways and processes during erosion of mountains is the mineral zircon (ZrSiO4), which is transported with sand (it is 'detrital') but is distinguished by its ability to have its formation age determined and thus serve as a fingerprint of the sediment source region (provenance). However, as proposed and demonstrated by outcomes of this research, using detrital zircon alone can lead to inaccurate determinations of provenance. This is due to the durability and insolubility of zircon in the Earth-surface environment. The detrital zircon grains tend to be recycled from one sediment-forming event to another, preserving a record of the ultimate source of the zircon, not the immediate source. The latter is the main goal of sedimentary provenance. In order to obtain a more accurate assessment of immediate provenance we proposed to employ three other geochronometers: (1) the (U-Th)/He method of dating detrital zircon (i.e., resulting in two dates for a single zircon grain - the time of crystallization and the time of uplift, erosion, and release of the zircon grain into the sedimentary system, or "double dating"); (2) the Th-Pb method of dating detrital monazite, which yields a metamorphic or diagenetic crystallization age; (3) (U-Th-Sm)/He dating of the same monazite grains dating by (2). We also characterized the textures of detrital monazite to discriminate between detrital diagenetic monazite, and metamorphic monazite, both of which prove recycling from older sediments or metasedimentary rocks. The double-dating of zircon and Th-Pb dating of monazite were succesful. In spite of having prelimary data on monazite standards, the (U-Th-Sm)/He dating of detrital monazite was found to be analytically too challenging for obtaining geologically meaningful ages on detrital metamorphic monazite. This was due to the complex growth history of monazite that often results in multiple age domains in metamorphic monazite. In spite of this disappointing outcome for goal (3), we made important discoveries for long-lived sedimentary systems. These include:

(1) Late Pennsylvanian (ca. 315 Ma), coal-bearing strata in the Appalachian basin were derived from two sources, which correlate with sandstone lithology: (A) immature, lithic arenites are derived directly via river systems flowing perpendicular to the orogen from clastic units in the Appalachian crystal core that had been metamorphosed in the Paleozoic (450-325 million years ago); (B) mature quartz sandstones possess an entirely different provenance, hvaing been delivered to the Appalachian Basin via river systems flowing parallel to the orogen from sources as far away as Ireland-Scotland and easternmost Canada. The immediate source was probably older mature quartz sandstones. The results of the geochronology support evidence published by previous workers for a dual, alternating source that correlates with episodes of thrust faulting during collision of North America with Africa.

(2) Double-dating of detrital zircon and textures in monazite prove that zircon is recycled multiple times - at least 3 can be demonstrated with up to 10 cycles being possible.

(3) Detrital monazite textures, specifically detrital diagenetic monazite, prove sedimentary recycling, in a manner similar to other petrologic and lithologic evidence in mature quartz arenites and conglomerates.

In addition to the primary goals of the research, we used the same samples to test for recycling using common lead (Pb) isotope analysis of detrital feldspar, a common mineral in sandstone whose Pb isotope composition is a fingerprint of continental basement source terranes. The results support our inference of recycling of late Precambrian clastic sediments from southeastern North America as a primary source for Pennsylvanian clastics in the Appalachian Basin. This work will serve as a basis for a future NSF proposal submission.

Three graduate students (1 female), one female undergraduate, and two high school students (1 female) conducted research supported by this award. All three graduates students are employed, the undergraduate is now a first year graduate student, and the high school students matriculated at research universities.

Multiple peer reviewed journal articles were published or are in review or revision. Multiple professional and guest lectures summarizing research results were presented.
